snippet: While the Security Council voted to sanction those who disrupt peace efforts, it stopped short of barring the warring factions from buying more arms.
abstract: United Nations Security Council adopts resolution to sanction those who disrupt peace initiatives in South Sudan, but does not stop warring factions from buying more weapons.

byline.original: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and ISMA'IL KUSHKUSH
byline.contributor: Somini Sengupta reported from the United Nations, and Isma’il Kushkush from Nairobi, Kenya.

lead_paragraph: While the Security Council voted to sanction those who disrupt peace efforts, it stopped short of barring the warring factions from buying more arms.

headline.main: U.N. Moves Closer to Sanctions in South Sudan Conflict
headline.print_headline: U.N. Moves Closer to Sanctions in South Sudan Conflict
